an5.76:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these five warriors are found in the world.

an5.76:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco yodhājīvo asicammaṃ gahetvā dhanukalāpaṃ sannayhitvā viyūḷhaṃ saṅgāmaṃ otarati.
an5.76:1.3.eng: Firstly, one warrior dons his sword and shield, fastens his bow and arrows, and plunges into the thick of battle.

an5.76:1.4.eng: He strives and struggles in the battle,

an5.76:1.5.pli: Tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare hananti pariyāpādenti.
an5.76:1.5.eng: but his foes kill him and finish him off.

an5.76:1.7.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo yodhājīvo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an5.76:1.7.eng: This is the first warrior found in the world.

an5.76:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco yodhājīvo asicammaṃ gahetvā dhanukalāpaṃ sannayhitvā viyūḷhaṃ saṅgāmaṃ otarati.
an5.76:2.1.eng: Furthermore, one warrior dons his sword and shield, fastens his bow and arrows, and plunges into the thick of battle.

an5.76:2.2.eng: He strives and struggles in the battle,

an5.76:2.3.pli: Tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare upalikkhanti, tamenaṃ apanenti;

an5.76:2.4.eng: He’s carried off and taken to his relatives,

an5.76:2.5.pli: So ñātakehi nīyamāno appatvāva ñātake antarāmagge kālaṃ karoti.
an5.76:2.5.eng: but he dies on the road before he reaches them.

an5.76:2.7.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo yodhājīvo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an5.76:2.7.eng: This is the second warrior found in the world.

an5.76:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco yodhājīvo asicammaṃ gahetvā dhanukalāpaṃ sannayhitvā viyūḷhaṃ saṅgāmaṃ otarati.
an5.76:3.1.eng: Furthermore, one warrior dons his sword and shield, fastens his bow and arrows, and plunges into the thick of battle.

an5.76:3.2.eng: He strives and struggles in the battle,

an5.76:3.3.pli: Tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare upalikkhanti, tamenaṃ apanenti;

an5.76:3.4.eng: He’s carried off and taken to his relatives,

an5.76:3.5.eng: who nurse him and care for him.

an5.76:3.6.pli: So ñātakehi upaṭṭhahiyamāno paricariyamāno teneva ābādhena kālaṃ karoti.
an5.76:3.6.eng: But he dies of his injuries while in their care.

an5.76:3.8.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyo yodhājīvo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an5.76:3.8.eng: This is the third warrior found in the world.

an5.76:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco yodhājīvo asicammaṃ gahetvā dhanukalāpaṃ sannayhitvā viyūḷhaṃ saṅgāmaṃ otarati.
an5.76:4.1.eng: Furthermore, one warrior dons his sword and shield, fastens his bow and arrows, and plunges into the thick of battle.

an5.76:4.2.eng: He strives and struggles in the battle,

an5.76:4.3.pli: Tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare upalikkhanti, tamenaṃ apanenti;

an5.76:4.4.eng: He’s carried off and taken to his relatives,

an5.76:4.5.eng: who nurse him and care for him.

an5.76:4.6.pli: So ñātakehi upaṭṭhahiyamāno paricariyamāno vuṭṭhāti tamhā ābādhā.
an5.76:4.6.eng: And while in their care, he recovers from his injuries.

an5.76:4.8.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, catuttho yodhājīvo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an5.76:4.8.eng: This is the fourth warrior found in the world.

an5.76:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco yodhājīvo asicammaṃ gahetvā dhanukalāpaṃ sannayhitvā viyūḷhaṃ saṅgāmaṃ otarati.
an5.76:5.1.eng: Furthermore, one warrior dons his sword and shield, fastens his bow and arrows, and plunges into the thick of battle.

an5.76:5.2.pli: So taṃ saṅgāmaṃ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmo tameva saṅgāmasīsaṃ ajjhāvasati.
an5.76:5.2.eng: He wins victory in battle, establishing himself as foremost in battle.

an5.76:5.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcamo yodhājīvo santo saṃvijjamāno lokasmiṃ.
an5.76:5.4.eng: This is the fifth warrior found in the world.

an5.76:5.5.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca yodhājīvā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an5.76:5.5.eng: These are the five warriors found in the world.

an5.76:6.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcime yodhājīvūpamā puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā bhikkhūsu.
an5.76:6.1.eng: In the same way, these five individuals similar to warriors are found among the monks.

an5.76:6.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā upanissāya viharati.
an5.76:6.3.eng: Firstly, a mendicant lives supported by a town or village.

an5.76:6.4.pli: So pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya tameva gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya pavisati arakkhiteneva kāyena arakkhitāya vācāya arakkhitena cittena anupaṭṭhitāya satiyā asaṃvutehi indriyehi.
an5.76:6.4.eng: He robes up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, enters a village or town for alms without guarding body, speech, and mind, without establishing mindfulness, and without restraining the sense faculties.

an5.76:6.5.pli: So tattha passati mātugāmaṃ dunnivatthaṃ vā duppārutaṃ vā.
an5.76:6.5.eng: There he sees a lady scantily clad, with revealing clothes.

an5.76:6.6.pli: Tassa taṃ mātugāmaṃ disvā dunnivatthaṃ vā duppārutaṃ vā rāgo cittaṃ anuddhaṃseti.

an5.76:6.7.pli: So rāgānuddhaṃsitena cittena sikkhaṃ apaccakkhāya dubbalyaṃ anāvikatvā methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭisevati.
an5.76:6.7.eng: and, without resigning the training and declaring his inability to continue, he indulges in sex.

an5.76:7.1.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo asicammaṃ gahetvā dhanukalāpaṃ sannayhitvā viyūḷhaṃ saṅgāmaṃ otarati, so tasmiṃ saṅgāme ussahati vāyamati, tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare hananti pariyāpādenti; tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi. Evarūpopi, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo hoti.
an5.76:7.1.eng: I say that this individual is like the warrior who is killed and finished off by his foes. Some individuals are like that.

an5.76:7.2.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṃvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
an5.76:7.2.eng: This is the first individual similar to a warrior found among the monks.

an5.76:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā upanissāya viharati.
an5.76:8.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant lives supported by a town or village.

an5.76:8.2.pli: So pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya tameva gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya pavisati arakkhiteneva kāyena arakkhitāya vācāya arakkhitena cittena anupaṭṭhitāya satiyā asaṃvutehi indriyehi.
an5.76:8.2.eng: He robes up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, enters a village or town for alms without guarding body, speech, and mind, without establishing mindfulness, and without restraining the sense faculties.

an5.76:8.3.pli: So tattha passati mātugāmaṃ dunnivatthaṃ vā duppārutaṃ vā.
an5.76:8.3.eng: There he sees a lady scantily clad, with revealing clothes.

an5.76:8.4.pli: Tassa taṃ mātugāmaṃ disvā dunnivatthaṃ vā duppārutaṃ vā rāgo cittaṃ anuddhaṃseti.

an5.76:8.5.pli: So rāgānuddhaṃsitena cittena pariḍayhateva kāyena pariḍayhati cetasā.
an5.76:8.5.eng: and his body and mind burn with it.

an5.76:8.7.eng: ‘Why don’t I visit the monastery and tell the monks:

an5.76:8.8.pli: rāgapariyuṭṭhitomhi, āvuso, rāgapareto, na sakkomi brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ;
an5.76:8.8.eng: “Reverends, I am overcome with lust, mired in lust. I am unable to keep up the spiritual life.

an5.76:8.9.eng: I declare my inability to continue training. I disavow it and will return to a lesser life.”’

an5.76:8.10.pli: So ārāmaṃ gacchanto appatvāva ārāmaṃ antarāmagge sikkhādubbalyaṃ āvikatvā sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
an5.76:8.10.eng: But while traveling on the road, before he reaches the monastery he declares his inability to continue training. He disavows it and returns to a lesser life.

an5.76:9.1.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo asicammaṃ gahetvā dhanukalāpaṃ sannayhitvā viyūḷhaṃ saṅgāmaṃ otarati, so tasmiṃ saṅgāme ussahati vāyamati, tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare upalikkhanti, tamenaṃ apanenti; apanetvā ñātakānaṃ nenti. So ñātakehi nīyamāno appatvāva ñātake antarāmagge kālaṃ karoti; tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi. Evarūpopi, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo hoti.
an5.76:9.1.eng: I say that they are like the warrior who is taken to his relatives for care, but he dies on the road before he reaches them. Some individuals are like that.

an5.76:9.2.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṃvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
an5.76:9.2.eng: This is the second individual similar to a warrior found among the monks.

an5.76:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā upanissāya viharati.
an5.76:10.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant lives supported by a town or village.

an5.76:10.2.pli: So pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya tameva gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya pavisati arakkhiteneva kāyena arakkhitāya vācāya arakkhitena cittena anupaṭṭhitāya satiyā asaṃvutehi indriyehi.

an5.76:10.3.eng: There he sees a lady scantily clad, with revealing clothes.

an5.76:10.4.pli: Tassa taṃ mātugāmaṃ disvā dunnivatthaṃ vā duppārutaṃ vā rāgo cittaṃ anuddhaṃseti.

an5.76:10.5.pli: So rāgānuddhaṃsitena cittena pariḍayhateva kāyena pariḍayhati cetasā.
an5.76:10.5.eng: and his body and mind burn with it.

an5.76:10.7.eng: ‘Why don’t I visit the monastery and tell the monks:

an5.76:10.8.pli: rāgapariyuṭṭhitomhi, āvuso, rāgapareto, na sakkomi brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ;
an5.76:10.8.eng: “Reverends, I am overcome with lust, mired in lust. I am unable to keep up the spiritual life.

an5.76:10.9.eng: I declare my inability to continue training. I disavow it and will return to a lesser life.”’

an5.76:10.10.eng: He goes to the monastery and tells the monks:

an5.76:10.11.pli: ‘rāgapariyuṭṭhitomhi, āvuso, rāgapareto, na sakkomi brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ;
an5.76:10.11.eng: ‘Reverends, I am overcome with lust, mired in lust. I am unable to keep up the spiritual life.

an5.76:10.12.eng: I declare my inability to continue training. I disavow it and will return to a lesser life.’

an5.76:11.1.eng: His spiritual companions advise and instruct him:

an5.76:11.2.pli: ‘appassādā, āvuso, kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.
an5.76:11.2.eng: ‘Reverend, the Buddha says that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.

an5.76:11.3.pli: Aṭṭhikaṅkalūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.
an5.76:11.3.eng: With the similes of a skeleton …

an5.76:11.4.pli: Maṃsapesūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.

an5.76:11.5.pli: Tiṇukkūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.

an5.76:11.6.pli: Aṅgārakāsūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.

an5.76:11.7.pli: Supinakūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.

an5.76:11.8.pli: Yācitakūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.

an5.76:11.9.pli: Rukkhaphalūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.

an5.76:11.10.pli: Asisūnūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.
an5.76:11.10.eng: a butcher’s knife and chopping board …

an5.76:11.11.pli: Sattisūlūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.

an5.76:11.12.pli: Sappasirūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.
an5.76:11.12.eng: a snake’s head, the Buddha says that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.

an5.76:11.13.eng: Be happy with the spiritual life.

an5.76:11.14.pli: māyasmā sikkhādubbalyaṃ āvikatvā sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattī’ti.
an5.76:11.14.eng: Venerable, please don’t declare your inability to continue training, disavow it and return to a lesser life.’

an5.76:12.1.pli: So sabrahmacārīhi evaṃ ovadiyamāno evaṃ anusāsiyamāno evamāha:
an5.76:12.1.eng: When thus advised and instructed by his spiritual companions, he says:

an5.76:12.2.pli: ‘kiñcāpi, āvuso, appassādā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo;
an5.76:12.2.eng: ‘Reverends, even though the Buddha says that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks,

an5.76:12.3.pli: atha kho nevāhaṃ sakkomi brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ, sikkhādubbalyaṃ āvikatvā sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissāmī’ti.
an5.76:12.3.eng: I am unable to keep up the spiritual life. I declare my inability to continue training. I disavow it and will return to a lesser life.’

an5.76:12.4.pli: So sikkhādubbalyaṃ āvikatvā sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
an5.76:12.4.eng: Declaring his inability to continue training, he disavows it and returns to a lesser life.

an5.76:14.5.eng: and his body and mind burn with it.

an5.76:14.7.eng: ‘Why don’t I visit the monastery and tell the monks:

an5.76:14.8.eng: “Reverends, I am overcome with lust, mired in lust. I am unable to keep up the spiritual life.

an5.76:14.9.eng: I declare my inability to continue training. I disavow it and will return to a lesser life.”’

an5.76:14.10.eng: He goes to the monastery and tells the monks:

an5.76:14.11.pli: ‘rāgapariyuṭṭhitomhi, āvuso, rāgapareto, na sakkomi brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ;

an5.76:15.1.eng: His spiritual companions advise and instruct him:

an5.76:15.2.pli: ‘appassādā, āvuso, kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.
an5.76:15.2.eng: ‘Reverend, the Buddha says that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.

an5.76:15.3.pli: Aṭṭhikaṅkalūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.
an5.76:15.3.eng: With the simile of a skeleton …

an5.76:15.4.pli: Maṃsapesūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā …pe… tiṇukkūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā … aṅgārakāsūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā … supinakūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā … yācitakūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā … rukkhaphalūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā … asisūnūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā … sattisūlūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā … sappasirūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.
an5.76:15.4.eng: a scrap of meat … a grass torch … a pit of glowing coals … a dream … borrowed goods … fruit on a tree … a butcher’s knife and chopping board … swords and spears … a snake’s head, the Buddha says that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.

an5.76:15.5.eng: Be happy with the spiritual life.

an5.76:15.6.pli: māyasmā sikkhādubbalyaṃ āvikatvā sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattī’ti.
an5.76:15.6.eng: Venerable, please don’t declare your inability to continue training, disavow it and return to a lesser life.’

an5.76:16.1.eng: When thus advised and instructed by his spiritual companions, he says:

an5.76:16.2.eng: ‘I’ll try, reverends, I’ll struggle, I’ll be happy.

an5.76:16.3.pli: Na dānāhaṃ, āvuso, sikkhādubbalyaṃ āvikatvā sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissāmī’ti.
an5.76:16.3.eng: I won’t now declare my inability to continue training, disavow it and return to a lesser life.’

an5.76:17.1.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo asicammaṃ gahetvā dhanukalāpaṃ sannayhitvā viyūḷhaṃ saṅgāmaṃ otarati, so tasmiṃ saṅgāme ussahati vāyamati, tamenaṃ ussahantaṃ vāyamantaṃ pare upalikkhanti, tamenaṃ apanenti; apanetvā ñātakānaṃ nenti, tamenaṃ ñātakā upaṭṭhahanti paricaranti. So ñātakehi upaṭṭhahiyamāno paricariyamāno vuṭṭhāti tamhā ābādhā; tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi.
an5.76:17.1.eng: I say that this individual is like the warrior who recovers from his injuries while in the care of his relatives.

an5.76:17.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, catuttho yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṃvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
an5.76:17.3.eng: This is the fourth individual similar to a warrior found among the monks.

an5.76:18.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā upanissāya viharati.
an5.76:18.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant lives supported by a town or village.

an5.76:18.2.pli: So pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya tameva gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā piṇḍāya pavisati rakkhiteneva kāyena rakkhitāya vācāya rakkhitena cittena upaṭṭhitāya satiyā saṃvutehi indriyehi.
an5.76:18.2.eng: He robes up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, enters a village or town, guarding body, speech, and mind, establishing mindfulness, and restraining the sense faculties.

an5.76:18.3.pli: So cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
an5.76:18.3.eng: Seeing a sight with his eyes, he doesn’t get caught up in the features and details.

an5.76:18.4.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati; rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ; cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
an5.76:18.4.eng: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, he practices restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving restraint over it.

an5.76:18.5.eng: Hearing a sound with his ears …

an5.76:18.6.eng: Smelling an odor with his nose …

an5.76:18.7.eng: Tasting a flavor with his tongue …

an5.76:18.8.eng: Feeling a touch with his body …

an5.76:18.9.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
an5.76:18.9.eng: Knowing an idea with his mind, he doesn’t get caught up in the features and details.

an5.76:18.10.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ manindriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati; rakkhati manindriyaṃ; manindriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
an5.76:18.10.eng: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, he practices restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving restraint over it.

an5.76:18.11.eng: Then after the meal, on his return from almsround,

an5.76:18.12.pli: vivittaṃ senāsanaṃ bhajati araññaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ pabbataṃ kandaraṃ giriguhaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjaṃ.
an5.76:18.12.eng: he frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.

an5.76:18.13.pli: So araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
an5.76:18.13.eng: Gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, he sits down cross-legged, sets his body straight, and establishes mindfulness in his presence.

an5.76:18.14.pli: So abhijjhaṃ loke pahāya …pe… so ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
an5.76:18.14.eng: He gives up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.

an5.76:18.15.pli: vivicceva kāmehi …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an5.76:18.15.eng: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, he enters and remains in the first absorption … second absorption … third absorption … fourth absorption.

an5.76:19.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṃ khayañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
an5.76:19.1.eng: When his mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—he extends it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.

an5.76:19.2.eng: He truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. He truly understands: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’. Knowing and seeing like this, his mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance. When freed, he knows ‘it is freed’.

an5.76:19.3.eng: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

an5.76:20.1.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo asicammaṃ gahetvā dhanukalāpaṃ sannayhitvā viyūḷhaṃ saṅgāmaṃ otarati, so taṃ saṅgāmaṃ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmo tameva saṅgāmasīsaṃ ajjhāvasati; tathūpamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imaṃ puggalaṃ vadāmi.
an5.76:20.1.eng: I say that this individual is like the warrior who dons his sword and shield, fastens his bow and arrows, and plunges into the thick of battle. He wins victory in battle, establishing himself as foremost in battle.

an5.76:20.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcamo yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṃvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
an5.76:20.3.eng: This is the fifth individual similar to a warrior found among the monks.

an5.76:20.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca yodhājīvūpamā puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā bhikkhūsū”ti.
an5.76:20.4.eng: These five individuals similar to warriors are found among the monks.”

an5.77:1.1.pli: “Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, anāgatabhayāni sampassamānena alameva āraññikena bhikkhunā appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharituṃ appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an5.77:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, seeing these five future perils is quite enough for a wilderness mendicant to meditate diligently, keenly, and resolutely for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

an5.77:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, āraññiko bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:

an5.77:2.3.eng: ‘Currently I’m living alone in a wilderness.

an5.77:2.4.pli: Ekakaṃ kho pana maṃ araññe viharantaṃ

an5.77:2.5.pli: ahi vā maṃ ḍaṃseyya, vicchiko vā maṃ ḍaṃseyya, satapadī vā maṃ ḍaṃseyya,
an5.77:2.5.eng: I might get bitten by a snake, a scorpion, or a centipede.

an5.77:2.6.pli: tena me assa kālaṅkiriyā, so mamassa antarāyo;
an5.77:2.6.eng: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to my progress.

an5.77:2.7.pli: handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.
an5.77:2.7.eng: I’d better rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’

an5.77:2.8.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ anāgatabhayaṃ sampassamānena alameva āraññikena bhikkhunā appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharituṃ appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an5.77:2.8.eng: This is the first future peril …

an5.77:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, āraññiko bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:

an5.77:3.2.eng: ‘Currently I’m living alone in a wilderness.

an5.77:3.4.pli: upakkhalitvā vā papateyyaṃ, bhattaṃ vā bhuttaṃ me byāpajjeyya, pittaṃ vā me kuppeyya, semhaṃ vā me kuppeyya, satthakā vā me vātā kuppeyyuṃ,
an5.77:3.4.eng: I might stumble off a cliff, or get food poisoning, or suffer a disturbance of bile, phlegm, or piercing winds.

an5.77:3.5.pli: tena me assa kālaṅkiriyā, so mamassa antarāyo;
an5.77:3.5.eng: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to my progress.

an5.77:3.6.pli: handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.
an5.77:3.6.eng: I’d better rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’

an5.77:3.7.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ anāgatabhayaṃ sampassamānena alameva āraññikena bhikkhunā appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharituṃ appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an5.77:3.7.eng: This is the second future peril …

an5.77:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, āraññiko bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:

an5.77:4.2.eng: ‘Currently I’m living alone in a wilderness.

an5.77:4.4.pli: vāḷehi samāgaccheyyaṃ, sīhena vā byagghena vā dīpinā vā acchena vā taracchena vā, te maṃ jīvitā voropeyyuṃ,
an5.77:4.4.eng: I might encounter wild beasts—a lion, a tiger, a leopard, a bear, or a hyena—which might take my life.

an5.77:4.5.pli: tena me assa kālaṅkiriyā, so mamassa antarāyo;
an5.77:4.5.eng: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to my progress.

an5.77:4.6.pli: handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.
an5.77:4.6.eng: I’d better rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’

an5.77:4.7.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ anāgatabhayaṃ sampassamānena alameva āraññikena bhikkhunā appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharituṃ appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an5.77:4.7.eng: This is the third future peril …

an5.77:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, āraññiko bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:

an5.77:5.2.eng: ‘Currently I’m living alone in a wilderness.

an5.77:5.4.pli: māṇavehi samāgaccheyyaṃ katakammehi vā akatakammehi vā, te maṃ jīvitā voropeyyuṃ,
an5.77:5.4.eng: I might encounter youths escaping a crime or on their way to commit one, and they might take my life.

an5.77:5.5.pli: tena me assa kālaṅkiriyā, so mamassa antarāyo;
an5.77:5.5.eng: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to my progress.

an5.77:5.6.pli: handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.
an5.77:5.6.eng: I’d better rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’

an5.77:5.7.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, catutthaṃ anāgatabhayaṃ sampassamānena alameva āraññikena bhikkhunā appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharituṃ appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an5.77:5.7.eng: This is the fourth future peril …

an5.77:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, āraññiko bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:

an5.77:6.2.eng: ‘Currently I’m living alone in a wilderness.

an5.77:6.3.pli: Santi kho panāraññe vāḷā amanussā, te maṃ jīvitā voropeyyuṃ,
an5.77:6.3.eng: But in a wilderness there are savage monsters who might take my life.

an5.77:6.4.pli: tena me assa kālaṅkiriyā, so mamassa antarāyo;
an5.77:6.4.eng: And if I died from that it would be an obstacle to my progress.

an5.77:6.5.pli: handāhaṃ vīriyaṃ ārabhāmi appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.
an5.77:6.5.eng: I’d better rouse up energy for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.’

an5.77:6.6.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcamaṃ anāgatabhayaṃ sampassamānena alameva āraññikena bhikkhunā appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharituṃ appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāya.
an5.77:6.6.eng: This is the fifth future peril …

an5.77:7.1.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, pañca anāgatabhayāni sampassamānena alameva āraññikena bhikkhunā appamattena ātāpinā pahitattena viharituṃ appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya asacchikatassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti.
an5.77:7.1.eng: These are the five future perils, seeing which is quite enough for a wilderness mendicant to meditate diligently, keenly, and resolutely for attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.”
